fr:title.text: Natural deduction proof system with weakening and "bud freshness"

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Natural deduction proof system with weakening and "bud freshness"

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This is a modification of our previous natural deduction system, which should behave more nicely with respect to \forall -reduction and cycle unfolding.

We omit variable labels of formulae in the context unless a rule interacts with the labels in some way. We also add to \mathcal {H} \vdash \Gamma the requirement that all variable labels in \Gamma are only used once (we could - and should - do this by making \Gamma a finite partial function from labels to formulae, in which case that requirement holds trivially).

The definition of cyclic proof is as usual, but we add the additional requirement that for a bud \mathcal {H} ; \Gamma \vdash \phi and a companion \mathcal {H}' ; \Gamma ' \vdash \phi ' there must be a bijection between \text {lbl}(\Gamma ) and \text {lbl}(\Gamma ') that induces a substitution of formulae variables \theta such that the domain and image of \theta are disjoint.

Reuben made a point that we need to be careful when weakening away labels and reintroducing them that no name clashes occur. We decided to adopt something that seems like a variant of Barendregt's variable convention - essentially, newly introduced labels and formula variables are considered fresh with respect to the entire proof below the rule instance that introduces them.

I wonder if nested cycles make this more complicated: if a weakening is good with respect to the "top-most" cycle, can you guarantee that it is good for any "sub-cycles" in the subproof above the companion? I have a feeling that you can guarantee this.

It also seems that if you start with a cyclic proof where weakenings are only used immediately after buds, then they will always be good with respect to any cycles that might be produced via unfolding. We need to prove that this is the case.

Objectives after this meeting:
Define weakening reduction, taking it to be stuck at a companion if the weakening is not good w.r.t. the cycle(s) corresponding to that companion. Pay extra care to possiblility of nested cycles, and also we should assume CNF as it looks like some of our intutions are based on taking it as given.
Define other reductions on "weakening normal forms", making sure that "good-ness of weakenings" is preserved by these.
Show that a proof where weakening rules are only used below buds doesn't get stuck in any reduction sequence.
Entailments in \mu HOL^{ex} can be constructed with the following natural deduction style inference rules.
